awd_titl_txt: Advancing and Supporting Female STEM faculty at a University in Transition
awd_abstract_narration:
The ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in areas such as policy, practice, culture, and organizational climate.  The ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (ADVANCE-IT) track supports the development of innovative organizational change strategies within an institution of higher education to enhance gender equity in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) academic workforce.

Villanova University (VU) is in a time of transition in leadership, strategic priority, and most importantly to its new national status as a Doctoral Research University.  The PIs propose to intentionally manage this transition to ensure that faculty, specifically STEM female and underrepresented minority (URM) faculty, flourish in the changing climate.  Three main thrusts will be orchestrated to accomplish their goals.  The first thrust, change management, will include retreats for administrators with a special focus on diversity and inclusion and faculty workshops focused on resilience during change.  Hiring, promotion, and assessment, the second thrust, will include diversity statements for job candidates; diversity and inclusion goals; funds for bringing candidates to campus; broad stakeholder bias training; and policy review for bias.  The final thrust, improving the culture for diversity, inclusion, and equity, will include administrator and faculty workshops on creating a diverse and equitable culture; workshops on allies, inclusive classrooms, and microaggressions; the expansion of intersectional conversations for faculty; leadership activities;  Employee Resource Groups (ERGs); and the training and support of faculty allies.  This ADVANCE IT project will result in new strategies to ensure equity for all STEM faculty during institutional transitions to increased research expectations of faculty.  . 

As part of the Villanova ADVANCE IT project, research on the effects of chairperson mindfulness training on departmental climate will be conducted. Biases are especially prevalent when people engage in automatic rather than controlled thinking and automatic thinking is more likely when psychological resources are low such as when people are coping with stress.  Mindfulness training has been shown to reduce stress and is at the cutting edge of psychological research and practice.  Given these elements, the proposed research intends to measure the impact of mindfulness training of department chairpersons' stress and the potential change in departmental climate from the perspective of departmental stakeholders.  The use of a randomized control group makes the experiment especially powerful as a way to isolate the effects of this training on departmental climate.  Furthermore, given the centrality of the academic department to institutional change during the transition to increasing research expectations of faculty, this focus is especially promising.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From 2018 to 2024, Villanova University embarked on an ambitious journey to build a strong culture of support and belonging within its academic community through the NSF-funded ADVANCE Institutional Transformation program. When first awarded this NSF grant, Villanova University was an institution in transition: transition in national status; in university leadership; and in strategic priorities, including faculty performance expectations. It was imperative that these institutional transitions were navigated in such a way that the faculty who have been shown to be vulnerable to shifting expectations participate in and benefit from the changes. During this time of transition, this project allowed Villanova to transform by both studying and managing these arising changes in faculty culture and expectations. This initiative harnessed principles of organizational change management to address the evolving needs of a growing institution and foster a more supportive environment for all. 

All award activity was rooted in Villanova's core values of Veritas (truth), Unitas (unity), and Caritas (love), aligning these ideals with initiatives designed to create more transparent and effective practices at the organizational level. At all points in the project, the work was grounded in Villanova's Augustinian Catholic mission, working across several of the University's strategic priorities and laying the foundation for long-lasting impact that would positively enhance all aspects of the faculty experience at Villanova. 

Key Accomplishments 

Transforming Hiring Practices 
Villanova improved its hiring culture through innovative program development. Workshops and associated training materials were developed to equip faculty and staff with the tools to build a robust candidate pool, promote transparent decision making throughout the candidate-evaluation process, reduce unintended influences, and ensure a fair, balanced, and compliant hiring process throughout. By 2024, a variety of resources were developed to provide search committees with expert guidance and support for their hiring initiatives. These efforts have solidified a culture of transparent, effective, and compliant hiring as a cornerstone of Villanova's recruitment strategy. 

Promoting Transparency in Promotion and Tenure 
The project prioritized evaluation of faculty assessment practices, particularly considering pandemic-related challenges. Significant collaborative work was done (across faculty stakeholders, department chairs, and college and university leadership) to establish the Villanova University Statement Documenting Impacts of COVID-19 on Faculty Scholarship, Teaching, and Service and to develop an explicit mechanism to recognize pandemic impacts as part of faculty tenure and promotion evaluations. Departments revisited promotion and tenure standards, addressing outdated language and norms. The Supplemental Funding Program supported external consultations for departmental reforms. Additionally, advocacy for expanded engagement of non-tenure-track faculty in governance processes led to promoting better recognition of faculty contributions to university mission across all ranks. 

Cultivating Faculty Leadership 
The project launched a comprehensive leadership development program for academic leaders, focusing in particular on department chairs and those in similar roles who often take on this crucial role without adequate orientation and training. Several hallmark programs were developed like the Campus Leaders Workshop, Academic Leaders Peer Network, New Academic Leaders Orientation, and Affiliated Faculty which provided various opportunities for training, collaboration, and growth. In parallel, an informal Faculty Engagement Council was established to unite efforts across campus, amplifying resources for faculty development and leadership. 

Leveraging Research to Drive Change 
A unique research project studied the effects of mindfulness training on academic leaders' stress management during institutional transformation, which yielded insights that informed leadership and faculty support initiatives. The research enabled by the grant resulted in numerous conference presentations, published conference proceedings, and a published peer-reviewed journal article, with several more currently in revision or preparation. The findings contribute to the developing literature on leadership and organizational change 

Building a Viable Future 
To ensure lasting impact, the project office established a governance structure, secured senior leadership buy-in, and developed long-term funding strategies that would continue beyond the end of the NSF grant period. These measures will sustain Villanova's commitment to mission-aligned leadership practices well beyond the grant period. 

A Model for Change 

Villanova's ADVANCE program not only transformed its own campus but also serves as a replicable model for other institutions undergoing significant transitions. By grounding work within the University mission and through a focus on leadership development, Villanova exemplifies how academic communities can thrive during times of transition through collaboration, innovation, and shared values.
